S3.T1.caption: TABLE I: Important Notations
S3.T1.table:
Symbol Description
N𝑁N number of clients
H𝐻H number of heterogeneous clusters
K𝐾K number of homogeneous clusters after K-Means
ℋesubscriptℋ𝑒\mathcal{H}_{e} set of heterogeneous clusters
ℋe,hsubscriptℋ𝑒ℎ\mathcal{H}_{e,h} set of clients in the hℎh-th heterogeneous cluster
ℋosubscriptℋ𝑜\mathcal{H}_{o} set of homogeneous clusters
ℋo,ksubscriptℋ𝑜𝑘\mathcal{H}_{o,k} set of clients in the k𝑘k-th homogeneous cluster
𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} local dataset on client i𝑖i
𝒟i~~subscript𝒟𝑖\tilde{\mathcal{D}_{i}} distilled dataset on client i𝑖i
𝒟gsubscript𝒟𝑔\mathcal{D}_{g} global dataset for pre-train
Ncsubscript𝑁𝑐N_{c} total number of label classes
C𝐶C number of label classes in local dataset of each client
ahsubscript𝑎ℎa_{h} cluster header in the hℎh-th heterogeneous cluster
𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} set of cluster header
𝒟hsubscript𝒟ℎ\mathcal{D}_{h} whole dataset on the hℎh-th cluster header
Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{i} soft label matrix generated by client i𝑖i
M𝑀M similarity matrix
ωtsuperscript𝜔𝑡\omega^{t} global model at communication round t𝑡t
ωhtsuperscriptsubscript𝜔ℎ𝑡{\omega}_{h}^{t} local model on the hℎh-th cluster header at communication round t𝑡t
ξht,ksuperscriptsubscript𝜉ℎ𝑡𝑘\xi_{h}^{t,k} a mini batch of data sampled from 𝒟hsubscript𝒟ℎ\mathcal{D}_{h}
η𝜂\eta learning rate
E1subscript𝐸1E_{1} number of epoch in pre-train at label knowledge collection stage
E2subscript𝐸2E_{2} number of epoch in local training at model training stage
B1subscript𝐵1B_{1} number of bits consumed for transmitting one model parameter
B2subscript𝐵2B_{2} number of bits consumed for transmitting one data sample
T𝑇T number of model communication rounds
references: The overall pipeline of our proposed HFLDD is shown in Fig. 1, and Table I summarizes the important notations. Briefly, HFLDD can be mainly divided into four parts: label knowledge collection, heterogeneous client clustering, IID dataset generation, and model training. Each part includes one or several steps. We will briefly introduce each part and the details will be shown in the following subsection.

S5.T2.caption: TABLE II: Communication cost when achieving given accuracy on MNIST under IID condition
S5.T2.table:
Metrics HFLDD FedAvg FedSeq
Accuracy=80% rounds/Accuracy 5/80.63% 17/80.54% 1/84.32%
Traffic (MB) 39.92M 593.15M 38.98M
Ratio 1X 14.86X 0.9765X
references:
In the scenario with IID data, we set the target test accuracy as 80.0% for the MNIST
dataset. Table II shows the number of rounds and communication cost for each
algorithm to reach the target test accuracy. The ratio denotes the multiple of the communication cost of each method relative to the HFLDD. It can be observed that the communication cost of HFLDD is slightly higher than that of FedSeq, and 14.86 times less than that of FedAvg. For the CIFAR10 dataset, we set the target accuracy as 70%. When each algorithm reaches the target test accuracy, the communication cost of HFLDD is still much smaller than that of FedAvg, while the communication cost consumed by FedSeq is 0.39 times that of HFLDD, as detailed in Table III. This is mainly because FedSeq converges faster than other algorithms when the data is IID.

When each algorithm reaches the target test accuracy, the communication cost of HFLDD is still much smaller than that of FedAvg, while the communication cost consumed by FedSeq is 0.39 times that of HFLDD, as detailed in Table III. This is mainly because FedSeq converges faster than other algorithms when the data is IID.

S5.T4.caption: TABLE IV: The impact of K𝐾K on the test accuracy of HFLDD
S5.T4.table:
The Value of K 5 6 7 8 9 10 11
MNIST (C=1𝐶1C=1) 95.2% 97.1% 97.3% 98.0% 98.0% 98.1% 98.1%
MNIST (C=2𝐶2C=2) 98.3% 98.0% 98.3% 98.3% 98.1% 98.3% 98.1%
MNIST (C=10𝐶10C=10) 98.5% 98.3% 98.5% 98.4% 98.3% 98.4% 98.4%
CIFAR10 (C=1𝐶1C=1) 54.4% 61.9% 60.6% 58.7% 61.8% 64.3% 61.3%
CIFAR10 (C=2𝐶2C=2) 70.8% 69.7% 70.8% 69.1% 68.9% 70.1% 68.2%
CIFAR10 (C=10𝐶10C=10) 73.5% 74.5% 74.4% 73.1% 72.4% 72.2% 71.3%
references:
In this part, we evaluate the impact of K𝐾K in the K-Means homogeneous client clustering on the performance of the proposed HFLDD. Table IV shows the test accuracies of HFLDD on the MNIST and CIFAR10 datasets under different values of K𝐾K. When C=1𝐶1C=1, on the CIFAR10 dataset, the test accuracy is the highest when K=10𝐾10K=10, and it shows a noticeable decline
as K𝐾K decreases or increases. However, on the MNIST dataset, the test accuracy
remains relatively unchanged as K𝐾K varies. This is because the MNIST dataset
is relatively simple, making its data patterns and features easy to capture and understand. In
this scenario, even if an inappropriate value of K𝐾K is selected, HFLDD still can easily learn the features in the MNIST dataset. When C=2𝐶2C=2 and C=10𝐶10C=10, the heterogeneity is mitigated, and there is partial overlap in label classes among different clients, leading to a certain degree of overlap in the feature space. The test accuracy on the two datasets remains relatively stable as the value of K𝐾K changes. From this, we observe that when data heterogeneity is not particularly severe, HFLDD exhibits robustness to the value of K𝐾K.
